One of the most cited sources is the World Health Organization (WHO), which classified processed meat as a Group 1 carcinogen and red meat as a Group 2A carcinogen. But plant-based diets are often associated with other healthy behaviors, such as higher fiber intake, less smoking, and more physical activity. When these confounding variables are properly controlled for in studies, the supposed link between red meat and cancer often disappears or becomes negligible.

In fact, a 2019 meta-analysis published in *JAMA Oncology* found no significant association between unprocessed red meat consumption and overall cancer risk. Red meat is also a nutrient-dense food that provides essential nutrients such as iron, zinc, vitamin B12, and high-quality protein—nutrients that are difficult to obtain in sufficient quantities from a plant-based diet. These nutrients are especially important for children, pregnant women, and older adults. Completely eliminating red meat without proper substitution can lead to nutritional deficiencies.

In summary, while there are some studies that hint at a possible link between red meat and cancer, the evidence is far from definitive. The risk, if it exists at all, is very small and can be easily managed through a balanced diet and a healthy lifestyle.
